repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Maranhao Integrated Program :
            Rural Poverty Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Maranhao Integrated
            Program for Rural Poverty Reduction Project for Brazil were
            as follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: a decentralized, rural Community-Driven
            Development (CDD) project in a very poor state with issues
            of institutional capacity at all levels and geographic
            dispersion may not be the best vehicle for introducing
            results-based management and similarly challenging
            activities involving complex vertical and horizontal
            linkages. While the Northeast CDD projects have, since
            inception, been vehicles for the successful piloting and
            scaling up of innovation, not all participating states have
            equal capacity to host innovation successfully. Innovation
            also needs consistent commitment and full understanding and
            buy-in of all stakeholders. Decentralized, community-based
            projects with broad geographic coverage require more
            frequent, technical and specialized missions including
            fiduciary and safeguard specialists. Other Northeast rural
            poverty reduction projects are now focusing much more on
            productive investments which have specialized technical and
            operational requirements. The ability of supervision
            missions to finance the inclusion of specialists is critical
            to the success of such activities, including via the
            training opportunity they can provide to state technical
            units for analyzing, approving and overseeing implementation
            of such subprojects.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Maranhao Integrated Program :
            Rural Poverty reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Maranhao Integrated Program for
            Rural Poverty Reduction for Brazil will help Maranhao
            achieve the goal of reducing poverty by increasing its
            United Nations Human Development Index (HDI) from 0.647 to
            0.700 by the year 2007. There are four project components
            which comprise (a) strengthening the results-based
            management capacity at the State level for planning,
            cross-sectoral integration, monitoring and evaluation of
            public policies and investments under Maranhao's
            Multi-Year Government Investment Plan (PPA); (b) supporting
            cross-sectoral integration of development actions at the
            municipal and local levels through the design and
            implementation of integrated municipal development plans and
            the introduction of State-municipal performance agreements;
            (c) financing demand-driven community investments for
            income-generation, health and sanitation, education,
            culture, environmental management and others impacting the
            HDI and environmental sustainability; and (d) strengthening
            municipal governance through the participation of community
            associations and municipal councils in decisions that are
            directly related to improvements in the living conditions of
            the rural poor, and through capacity-building focused on
            integration of environmental sustainability issues in the
            decision-making process.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Maranhao Integrated Rural
            Development Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Maranhao Integrated Rural
            Development Project seeks to reduce rural poverty by
            financing investments (subprojects), and strengthening
            community organizations, through integrated, sustainable
            environmental actions. Given the nature of this project, and
            the existence of a number of indigenous populations, and
            ethnic groups living in the project area, this Indigenous
            Peoples Plan (IPP) sets the framework to ensure their
            participation, and that they also share the project's
            economic benefits. Public awareness campaigns should
            disseminate information on the implementation of the
            program, taking into account language diversity, cultural
            heritage, and traditional ways of life, in order to
            facilitate access to communal benefits. Nongovernmental
            organizations, and experienced organizations in indigenous
            matters, shall survey community requirements in a
            participatory approach, to comply with the state, and
            municipal development plans, and define/prioritize the
            communities' demands. Capacity building, and training
            shall be provided for community management, organizational
            skills, and for agricultural productivity activities, among
            others. Such training shall focus on empowering communities
            towards managing their own subprojects, in the areas of food
            products, infrastructure development that complement
            education, and health activities; and, basic infrastructure
            - water supply and sanitation, electricity, and improved
            transportation modes, - and, support for the promotion of
            cultural activities. Monitoring criteria should ensure
            compliance with the guidelines, as set forth in this document.

Brazil - Maranhao Integrated Rural
            Development Project : indigenous peoples plan

2896125.projn:
BR-Maranhao Integrated Program: Rural

2896125.subsc: General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Maranhao Integrated Rural
            Development Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Maranhao Integrated Rural
            Development Project aims at reducing rural poverty by
            financing investments (subprojects), and strengthening
            community organizations, as well as through the integration
            of sustainable environmental actions. To this end,
            subprojects will be identified, and selected in accordance
            with their capacity to generate income, and employment
            through protective environmental conservation actions.
            Notwithstanding the environmental nature of this project,
            this environmental assessment stipulates the following
            mitigation measures. Capacity building will be provided for
            adequate technical practices on the use of agricultural
            machinery, and conservation measures for soil preparation,
            as it concerns crop sowing, and harvesting. Subprojects
            concerning agroindustries, should consider its site location
            at considerable distance from rivers or natural water flows
            to minimize water pollution, and in areas with adequate
            wastewater drainage, while the use of septic tanks, and
            fencing the perimeter should be further considered. The use
            of compost from residues should be practiced, in addition to
            biodegradable substances, and organic residues'
            transformation processes for soil preparation as needed.
            Solid wastes should be collected, and disposed of at
            selected landfills, or recycled as possible as per standards
            regulations. Management of irrigation systems should take
            into consideration minimal water requirements, to protect
            aquatic ecosystems, and, minimize detours on natural river
            flows, to include as well regulatory measures for the
            sustainable use of groundwater. Crop storage requires the
            use of appropriate tanks, located at considerable distance
            from river, and water flows. Finally, livestock management
            practices should consider "rotation" pastures
            controlling the number of animals, for vegetative, and soil
            preservation purposes.

Brazil - Maranhao Integrated Rural
